response.answer_text: Nothing can be true except objectively. Anything else is either an opinion, a perception, a preference, a philosophy, a value, a guess, a hope, a belief, an error, a delusion, or a lie. All of these are subjective. One big problem with philosophical questions is that they produce philosophical answers—which seemingly never seek the simple and practical answer that resolves the issue, but rather to identify and examine what kind of philosophers are involved in the discussion, and/or what kinds of philosophies are being used, and/or what kinds of philosophical errors are being made. Of course, this is starting out as one of those answers. But I'll get to the practical answer in a moment. First, how do you make an answer practical rather than scholarly-but-useless? Answer: By being specific. That is, instead of just speaking in terms of logical forms and logical models using such nondescript inputs such as anything, something, “a thing,” or “no thing,” use specific examples in our forms and models. This forces us to see whether our claims are valid. It also helps us, in this case, to realize what kinds of “things” we are dealing with—which cuts to the heart of the issue. This enables us to see whether our claims are valid. It also helps us, in this case, to realize the kinds of “things” we’re dealing with that can be true—which cuts to the heart of the issue. You see, the only things that can be true (or false) are various kinds of predicative statements—assertions about some aspects of reality. These can be called propositions, claims, confessions, accusations, assumptions, avowals, declarations, deductions, and so on. My point is, these all consist entirely of words, but are not just words that name things—or nouns. Rather, they involve a subject and a verb. Too often on Quora people attribute truth or falsity to a single noun that, by itself, does not make a predicative statement. Or, they ask whether a noun is “true” or “false.” For example, at any given moment, there is a debate ongoing on somewhere on Quora over whether “evolution” is true. Or “religion.” Or a specific religion (usually, “Christianity”). Or some other ism. But none of these can be “true” or “false.” Each of these terms merely identifies a discipline, a broad theory, or a rationale or method that contains multiple claims and assumptions—each of which may (and probably should) be evaluated for truthfulness separately. So, making statements such as “Evolution is a fact” (which I’ve seen too many times) is utter nonsense. Or, “Religion is false [or even true].” Again, nonsense. Now, the statements themselves are assertions and are therefore either true or false. (Okay, if you say, “Evolution happens,” now you have a predicative statement—one that is either true or false.) And the truthfulness or falsity of each statement is objective. (The two above are both false.) All we need to do to know that things true are objectively true, and that things false are objectively false, is to specify several statements about reality we know to be either true or false. Then, each ask ourselves: How do I know this is true? or How do I know this is false? I submit you can only know objectively—or you don’t know. And I’m sure my just saying that doesn’t prove and will not convince anyone. But you may be able to convince yourself if you do the exercise. This assumes you know something—at least one thing in this world—to be true or false. If you’re one of those who insists nothing can be known with certainty, then you consent that you don’t know anything and are thus unqualified—either way—to decide. Now, I intend (in the comments) to come up with my own list of things some of us know to be true. Also, I’ll see if I can come up with some we know to be false. For contrast, I’ll also come up with some things that are opinions, perceptions, lies, and such, to show how some are necessarily subjective—as well as how even these, though subjective, exist (or occur) objectively. As a disclaimer, I don’t claim this will “prove” anything to anyone. That’s not my purpose here, because I hold that proving is each person’s private responsibility. _||_ock

A: Welcome to Philosophy: the only field that doesn’t require you to assume an interpretive answer to this question. Rather, it requires you to think — logically, on one view — about the implications of all the possible answers. As such, since you’ve asked a philosophical question, I’ll give a philosophical answer: It’s pretty complicated.  Well, we could answer with “no, no thing can be objectively true;” but, in doing so, we’ve identified a thing that is objectively true: the fact that no thing is. We could, contrarily, answer with “yes, some thing can be objectively true;” but, then we’d have to devise and justify a methodology to prove that some things can be objectively true. Epistemological nihilists are those who outright deny the possibility of knowledge; i.e., they would go with the former answer. To argue for their position, they might say, “okay, fine, I concede: “some thing can be objectively true;” but, there’s only one thing that is so: the fact that “no thing can be objectively true.” But, they’d still have to prove that there is no other thing that can be objectively true. But, mind you, they really ought to do this by the same standards by which they ‘proved’ that that one thing is true — not just by simply restating that (supposed) ‘fact.’ That is no easy task. But, neither is the modus operandi of the Epistemological Realist. This position disagrees and claims that “knowledge is possible:” i.e., they take the latter answer. Epistemological Realists must, therefore, ‘prove’ the objective truth of some set of things for their answer to be ‘objectively’ justifiable. However, in troth, neither interlocutor seems to have much of a case either way — well, if they’re being honest with themselves. I mean, neither (seems to) have a ‘definite’ methodology nor a ‘definite’ fact from which to start.

No. That’s why we make a distinction between objective and subjective. Once you accept that the external world existed before you, will exist after you, and exists in its own right, independent of your short existence and limited consciousness, that is when you can make the distinction between objective and subjective, and can then become incrementally more objective from your permanently subjective internal state. Yes, you can never be totally objective, due to being a subjective being, yet you can become more objective by using more objective methods. No reason to quit if you can’t have it all. Can anything be objectively true? Everything that is actually so, is objectively and truly so. The only things that are not so are constructs in/from the subjective mind, aka imagination. If something is so then you are not imagining it. If you imagine something, that does not make it so. There are a situational exceptions, that you can imagine something and it can later turn out to be so, either because you had no knowledge that it already existed when you imagined it, or when you take action to make something that you imagined so by physically making it happen. I would suggest not being fooled into thinking there is no real difference between subjective and objective by the exceptions. Subjective - The internal view of the world.Objective - All that does exist in the world. Objective is also used to describe methods for the subjective being to become more objective, or change their subjective view to align more closely with the real world. So when we call a person objective we are describing someone with a low imaginary world view and a higher alignment with what is actually so. The word objective being used both ways can lead to some confusion on this topic.

Great question. That’s the big problem of science. No, no thing can be objectively true. A good example of the reasoning for this are Descartes Meditationes. In this he argues (as if he had seen The Matrix) that everything could just be a dream, or a setup of a mischievous god. Only one thing he can be sure about: Cogito, ergo sum. (Back then, the stance of everything else being the matrix and thus untrue was called Solipsism) I would translate Cogito, ergo sum not literally as “i think, therefore i am” but rather as “i experience, therefore i am” or “i am conscious, therefore i am”. You have to see that Descartes divided the world into the res cogitans and the res extensa. So the extended world, the bodily world, and the thinking world, the world in which the thinking takes place. This world is our consciousness (actually the outside world takes place there too, somehow, but let’s not get too crazy). So what Descartes actually says is: the only thing you can be sure of is that you are conscious, that you are alive, that you are. Else there wouldn’t be anyone asking this question. Everything else is uncertain. This reality is uncertain. Every sentence trying to describe it is only an assumption. Someone once said: The map is not the territory. And it will never be. How would a sentence be equivalent to what it describes? Many philosophers have boggled their minds with this question and haven’t found an objective answer. Maybe that’s reason enough to trust it. Although also this sentence is only an assumption. Nothing is sure, not even the uncertainty. If you stop striving for certainty, you may live happier. On the other hand, objectively true sentences can be formed from a basis of other sentences. This is logic. It is what mathematics are build of. Use some axioms, prove what follows from them. So you can build maps that are self-consistent. The funny thing is that reality is very well describable using the method of logic. That’s what makes me wonder the most about this reality. Why does science work so well, even though it’s plan is never achievable? It’s crazy!

An objective truth is some attribute of reality many people who never communicated would nevertheless all agree on. Some philosophers would argue against the existence of objective truth, on the grounds that we know reality only filtered through biased and unreliable senses, and objective truth is about them, not “reality”. Others would argue that reality only exists because our observations create it. Still others would argue there’s really only one of us, and he’s dreaming anyway. Despite this, all these philosophers eat breakfast and wear clothes, almost as if there were some point to that.

You ask A2A: “Can anything be objectively true?” Yes. Things are. Therefore, things are objectively true. (Circular, I know, but if nothing is, what's the point?) The more important question to my mind is whether or to what extent can we know what is objectively true. My model, based upon my own experience, is that our several subjective experiences of reality or “truth” tend to approach objective truth as a limit. The more subjective experiences collected, the closer our approximations of objective truth. (If there is no convergence, seek a different definition.)

I was brought up with the notion that all we have to do is discover the truths that are out there, and then apply them. Now we are realizing that things that we once thought were absolute truths are really forms of evidence that have an infinite number of variables attached to them that we can't possibly factor in because of the limitless qualities. Therefore we are stuck with incomplete concepts that we can still use as valuable guidelines, but not as the perfect absolutes we once thought they were. A great example is health. We all know that diet and exercise correlate with good health, but the specific behaviors are going to be different for everyone. Each of us can experiment on what works best for us based on the guidelines, but we will never know exactly what's best for us, and we will have to continually approximate and make adjustments based on the feedback our individual bodies give us. Relationships are another example where these same formulas apply.

Can anything be objectively true? I look upon objectivity as species-subjectivity: i.e. all the normally functioning brains of a species grasp perceived reality in the same way. From this perspective many, many things are objectively true. In fact, in this sense, the the major portion of scientific knowledge is, at any phase of the history of science, objectively true, as are mathematical propositions. Trust all is well at Chapel Hill. Peace!! 30 April 2018

This hinges on what objective means and what true means. To me, objective is contrasted with subjective. Subjective is all about my personal experience. Objective is what we “all” agree about common subjective experiences. For me the idea of something that is out there, that exists regardless of our experience, doesn't make sense. Sure it could BE there, but so what? If it doesn't affect us and we cannot experience its effects, it is best ignored as not being there. And what about experiences that most of us have and some don't? Or some of us have and most don't? Are the things we experienced really “out there” or just collective or individual delusions? And how do you as an individual decide between the two? And we haven't even started on what true means!

Presumably you mean ‘Are there objective truths?’ Truth is not an object; it’s a property of meaningful propositions. But of course there are objective truths. ‘There is a black mug on my desk right now’ is an objectively true proposition. It’s not particularly meaningful or important, but it’s true. And any one of us can generate an infinite number of these should we so desire. ‘Truth’ is only a linguistic property

Everything that is perceived is objectively true. Only truth is perceivable. Our perception is the language of truth. However, the deceptive point about objectivity is our missing out of the fact that an object is only partially perceivable. The other associated deceptive point about it is our unreasonable demand for complete perception of an object and our being fanatic against accepting a course of perception if less than complete. When you are looking at a sandbank, you are certainly seeing sand, although you are not yet aware of the number of sands you are looking on. Does it mean that you don’t know the sandbank, just because you don’t know the number of sands it is made up of? Does it mean that the sandbank isn’t objectively true, because of the aforesaid shortfall in knowing? Does a candle’s glow is to be reckoned by the darkness that borders it?

Everything that one thinks or perceives (perception is reality) to exist (concretely or conceptually) is entirely subjective. ALL truth and thought is subjective. The most objective true statement that one can make is: “All concepts and perceptions are subjective” and even that is only subjectively true. The only objective truths consist of tautological truths i.e., things which are true in that they are defined as such. This includes math, logic, and other rules based systems. Even these systems are subjective to the perceiver and are not necessarily universally true as they depend on the beliefs of each perceiver. Perception is REALITY. The only means to be truly objective is on a meta level so that our subjectivity itself can be objectified viewed from outside of physical and mental reality. See: Bert Leysath's answer to Is there any objective truth in philosophy or is it all relative?

Can anything be objectively true?  Yes. For example, can we know objectively if X is healthy for human beings or is not? Yes. Is drinking battery acid a good thing for human biological health? No. This is objective. Objective truth is part of the world and the mind of mankind.

I found a method where there are objective truths in one degree using the process of elimination. However, there are a number of exceptions to the system which are also possible. For more on that (and understand the assumptions of the system have to be understood in the right way and is only one of many applications, for example, it may not be the best application for subjectivity, or understanding humans, or having technical knowledge about how to repair a refrigerator, etc …), see: Nathan Coppedge's answer to What is categorical deduction?

“Can anything be objectively true?” There is no alternative. Even if it were claimed to be true that nothing is objectively true, that very claim, viz., “nothing is objectively true”, would have to be objectively true! (Which of course is a conclusion that contradicts its premise, so it must be false to claim “nothing is objectively true.”)

Those who advocate that truth is not objective, i.e., that there is no objective standard on earth, say that you (and I) cannot know anything for sure. They say there are no absolutes. Yet, note such an agnostic's irrational thinking here. He is sure that you cannot be sure of anything. He knows you cannot know anything. Is this not a glaring double standard? Why would one claim to be so smart and yet allow himself to remain inconsistent, with an air of being an expert in epistemology? One thing we do know is that it is personally "convenient" and at times politically and economically expedient to remain an agnostic. This is the real intellectual, you know! It is popular in many circles today to be ridiculously "open-minded" in that some are so open-minded that their brains have fallen out and their thinking process is flawed. Such is the case when one foolishly argues he can know, but you can't know. But, John 17:17 and John 8:32. Thanks for allowing me to throw in my two cents.

>>>Is there objective truth?<<< No. Truth is a subjective construct. >>>Is it a truth that there is no truth” No. It is a proclamation that there is no truth. Proclamation of truth or no truth is not identical with truth or no truth.
Everything with a physical reality is OBJECTively true for everyone, as long as they can perceive it. However, everything in physical reality will have a different SUBJECTive meaning to everyone.
I suggest that ultimate Truth transcends the objective-subjective dichotomy.

Depends on what you are talking about. Scientific facts are the closest we come to objective truths, truths that are correct even if there were no humans to measure them, that are not dependent on human observations. But all human values, beliefs, and judgments are subjective and relative.

Yes. Try dropping an iron on your head and say to yourself “there is no iron.” I imagine if you are not dead and you have a working set of nerves, you will not be able to effectively deny the objective truth that an iron was dropped on your head. Your nerves will be your witnesses.

Absolute, transcendent, timeless truth is objective—true whether believed or not. Rape is wrong all the time for everyone, and that’s objectively true as a moral principle from a moral Lawgiver. Objective truth doesn’t depend upon your opinions, worldview, or influences.

The first fact is that exist for you cannot deny it without asserting you exist.; the first principle of contradiction is self -evident; then there is the mind's aptitude for truth. All of these are objectively true.
Yes - well, Truth is. :)
are you buying. or selling.
